description.plain:
System of a Down, also known by the acronym ‘SOAD’ and often shortened to ‘System,’ are an Armenian four-piece rock band from Southern California, formed in 1994.




The band achieved commercial success with the release of five studio albums, and Toxicity, Mezmerize and Hypnotize have all debuted at number one on the Billboard 200. System of a Down has been nominated for four Grammy Awards, and their song “B.Y.O.B.” won the Best Hard Rock Performance of 2006.



(Toxicity’s album art)

The group briefly disbanded in August 2006 and reunited in November 2010, embarking on a tour for the following three years. They had two subsequent worldwide tours in 2015 and 2017.

System of a Down has sold over 40 million records worldwide, and two of their singles, “Aerials” and “Hypnotize,” reached number one on Billboard’s Alternative Songs chart.




The band currently consists of four Armenian Americans:

Serj Tankian: lead vocals, keyboards, guitar on occasion.
Daron Malakian: vocals, guitar.
Shavo Odadjian: bass, backing vocals.
John Dolmayan: drums.



(SOAD’s actual formation)

songs.full_title: Chop Suey! by System of a Down

description.plain:
Rick Rubin, who produced Toxicity for System of a Down, cites this song as one of his most important projects. He told Rolling Stone:

This song was originally going to be called “Self-Righteous Suicide,” and the record company rebelled. …I remember wanting to go to the mat and keep the title, and the band decided, “Let’s call it ‘Chop Suey!’” which I thought was kind of funny.

Chop-suey is the Americanization of the Chinese quick dish tsap sui, which means “odds and ends, mixed bits” in the Cantonese dialect. The song title is a play on “Self-right-Chop Suey-cide,” that has a further sort of humor in that they mixed up a controversial word into a nonsensical word to create a more ‘radio-friendly’ title.

The song enjoyed success, climbing the charts after its August 2001 release before virtually disappearing from airways after 9/11. The song’s chorus, with its congratulatory “self-righteous suicide,” and lament, “I cry when angels deserve to die” was considered a bit too raw for listeners at the time. In the wake of the tragedy, Clear Channel Communications (now iHeartMedia) put out a memo to its subsidiary radio stations  temporarily blackballing (but not outright banning) it, along with 164 other “lyrically questionable” songs. Eventually, the record resurfaced on the charts—in part due to its earlier popularity, in part due to the lack of new singles released that September. However, it remains one of System of a Down’s worst performing US singles, particularly relative to the song’s global performance.

Although the lyrics are viewed as confrontational, the singer is actually challenging the listener to “wake up” and reconsider the way that they judge and deride people who are engaged in self-destructive behaviors. The song culminates in a biblical connection to Jesus before his death on the cross, with the singer ostensibly having chosen his “self-righteous suicide” so that these ‘sinners’ would be forgiven.

songs.embed_content: Read “Chop Suey!” by System of a Down on Genius

songs.full_title: Toxicity by System of a Down

description.plain: “Toxicity” is one of System of a Down’s biggest hits, the song reached No. 70 on Billboard Hot 100 and No. 3 on Mainstream Rock chart. During a performance at the 2005 Download Festival, Daron Malakian said that the song was about Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), a learning disorder that causes a person to have trouble concentrating, etc. The video for the song was directed by the band’s bassist Shavo Odadjian, just like “Aerials” video.

songs.full_title: B.Y.O.B. by System of a Down

description.plain:
“B.Y.O.B.” (“Bring Your Own Bombs”) is the first single released from American heavy metal band System of a Down’s fourth album Mezmerize.

Like their earlier song “Boom!,” it was written in protest against the Iraq War.

B.Y.O.B. means “Bring Your Own Bombs,” as opposed to the common interpretation “Bring Your Own Booze,” referring to the Iraq War as one big party for the United States, where instead of Jägerbombs they drop real ones.

It made onto numerous “Top 40” playlists around the globe, including Germany, New Zealand, Australia and the United States, and occasionally made it to #1 on other music shows.

Like their earlier song “Boom!,” it was written in protest against the Iraq War.

B.Y.O.B. means “Bring Your Own Bombs,” as opposed to the common interpretation “Bring Your Own Booze,” referring to the Iraq War as one big party for the United States, where instead of Jägerbombs they drop real ones.

It made onto numerous “Top 40” playlists around the globe, including Germany, New Zealand, Australia and the United States, and occasionally made it to #1 on other music shows.

songs.full_title: Aerials by System of a Down

description.plain:
“Aerials” was released in June, 2002 as the third single from System of a Down’s second album Toxicity, which itself was released in September, 2001.  It was critically and commercially successful; the song was nominated for Best Hard Rock Performance at the 2003 Grammy Awards.



The overall theme of the song is our mistaken views of ourselves as being individual and isolated from the rest – mankind and other lifeforms – and how we actually are a tiny part of something greater, from which we come when we are born, and to which we go when we die. It speaks of clinging to life and not accepting death, ‘cause we see death as an ending, not as another step of existence. When we die, our matter is decomposed and is transferred to things like worms that feed on us, to the atmosphere in the form of gas, and to the ground and plants that feed on him. We are always moving through the circle of existence, there is no stillness, only movement and transformation.

On many CD issues, “Aerials” is listed as a single track with a length of 6:11. In reality, “Aerials” itself ends at around 3:54, while the rest of the length is taken up by a hidden track unofficially named “Arto.”

songs.embed_content: Read “Aerials” by System of a Down on Genius

songs.full_title: Sugar by System of a Down

description.plain:
Sugar is an American obsession. It is in all of our food and we have basically become addicted to it.

The term ‘sugar’ is also a well-known euphemism for cocaine, which has even worse addictive effects than sugar itself.

songs.embed_content: Read “Sugar” by System of a Down on Genius

songs.full_title: Hypnotize by System of a Down

description.plain: “Hypnotize” is the eponymous debut single of System of a Down’s fifth album. The song talks about how governments manipulate (or “hypnotize”) people, essentially placating them and keeping them focused on propaganda so they can maintain control over the people over whom they rule.

songs.embed_content: Read “Hypnotize” by System of a Down on Genius

I'm just sitting in my car and waiting for my... girl

songs.full_title: Lonely Day by System of a Down

description.plain:
“Lonely Day” is a song by System of a Down, from Hypnotize. Contrary to popular belief, this song is not about Daron Malakian’s brother, because he is an only child. He wrote this song and provides lead vocals on it. This song has a heavy guitar solo at the end, with a dreary theme throughout.

The song appeared in Disturbia, a 2007 movie starring Shia LeBeouf which was about a kid who stays on house arrest and watches his neighbors to pass the time. The song appeared in a sequence in the movie where Shia’s character tries to find ways of keeping himself from dying of boredom.

songs.embed_content: Read “Lonely Day” by System of a Down on Genius

songs.full_title: Soldier Side by System of a Down

description.plain: A song decrying war. Daron said he could strongly relate to mothers whose sons were going out to fight. Based on that emotion he wrote the song.

songs.embed_content: Read “Soldier Side” by System of a Down on Genius

songs.full_title: Prison Song by System of a Down

description.plain: “Prison Song” is a criticism of the prison-industrial complex, the war on drugs, and the incredibly high rate of incarceration in America compared to other modern nations. The track opens SOAD’s best-selling album, Toxicity, reflection the main structure on most of the album’s songs: a mixture of melody and screaming, metal and pop, Serj Tankian and Daron Malakian.

songs.full_title: Violent Pornography by System of a Down

description.plain:
“Violent Pornography” is a commentary on the degrading nature of television and media in general on our culture and intelligence. Featuring explicit vocals, the track talks about things nobody wants to talk about.

Kirk Hammett of Metallica named the song the 16th best of the first decade of the 2000’s.

songs.full_title: Lost In Hollywood by System of a Down

description.plain: Seems to be a grim illustration of how Hollywood takes normal people looking to fulfill dreams of being an actor/actress, and then viciously changing them into fake people. Some may say actors live a double life, acting one way in movies, another in public, and even another in their personal lives. Fame can do tragic things to people. Jim Morrison, Kurt Cobain, and Janis Joplin are icons, living legends that died before their time. Others fame completely destroys.

songs.full_title: Spiders by System of a Down

description.plain: The fifth track and second single of System of a Down’s 1998 self-titled debut album. It speaks of June, a girl going through a procedure to insert a v-chip in her brain, controlling her thoughts and dreams. It metaphorically speaks of the control imposed on our will by the government, the media and the system. “Spiders” is a fan favorite track for its haunting atmosphere and powerful vocal performance of Serj Tankian.

Before you know, awake

Through her hair

Through her hair

It speaks of June, a girl going through a procedure to insert a v-chip in her brain, controlling her thoughts and dreams. It metaphorically speaks of the control imposed on our will by the government, the media and the system. “Spiders” is a fan favorite track for its haunting atmosphere and powerful vocal performance of Serj Tankian.

songs.full_title: Cigaro by System of a Down

description.plain:
“Cigaro” details the pointless and seemingly endless obsession of ‘Boys and their Toys’, whether it be the explicit concept of penis size or the size of their guns, men are always trying to prove their superiority over one another.

Serj & Daron criticize the corporate and political bosses that sit back, smoke their cigars, and talk complete shit to further their already grossly inflated ego’s and public profiles while ignoring laws and restrictions imposed (by them) and promoting their products to the population.

songs.full_title: Deer Dance by System of a Down

description.plain:
“Deer Dance” is about police brutality against peaceful protesters who are standing up for what they believe in but to no avail. Some parts of the song are just Serj Tankian talking about how is to be in a manifestation and how the authority treats you. In others, he talks about the importance of the protests to change your local community or maybe the world, like it seems on the bridge:

A deer dance
Invitation to peace
War starring you in the face

songs.full_title: Question! by System of a Down

description.plain:
“Question!” is the second single off of SOAD’s fourth album Mezmerize. The song alternates between five different time signatures – 5/4, 9/8, 6/4, ¾, and 4/4 – giving a wildly irregular, yet melodic, rhythm.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ENBv2i88g6Y

The music video for the song features a boy and a girl portrayed in different stages of their lives, onstage as though in a play. In the end, the girl eats berries and dies and the boy grieves her death, before the cycle of life repeats. The concept for the video was proposed by bassist Shavo Odadjian.

The song could be interpreted as the pondering of the afterlife, or the possibilities of reincarnation. He is wondering if our life completely ends when we physically die, or if our spirit remains.

songs.full_title: Needles by System of a Down

description.plain:
“Needles” is a song that talks about the danger of abusing drugs, more specifically heroin, comparing it to have a parasite in your body; the band advertises everybody, don’t do drugs—pull the tapeworm out of your ass!

The song has also more Daron Malakian’s vocal appearance, but is a little more melodic, as he said:

I wanted to add a bit more harmony for myself in the songs and that required tastefully mixing in some softer guitars between the really heavy parts.

body.plain:
“Needles” is a song that talks about the danger of abusing drugs, more specifically heroin, comparing it to have a parasite in your body; the band advertises everybody, don’t do drugs—pull the tapeworm out of your ass!

The song has also more Daron Malakian’s vocal appearance, but is a little more melodic, as he said:

I wanted to add a bit more harmony for myself in the songs and that required tastefully mixing in some softer guitars between the really heavy parts.

annotatable.title: Needles
annotatable.link_title: Needles by System of a Down

songs.full_title: Vicinity of Obscenity by System of a Down

description.plain: Daron said in an interview that Serj wrote this song and that none of them had any idea whatsoever what it meant, they were just having fun. This is also backed by Serj, who stated on Reddit that the song is about Dadaism. However, it could still be interpreted any number of different ways.

songs.full_title: Radio/Video by System of a Down

description.plain:
“Radio/Video” is dedicated to the band members that left the band in the early years (when the band was named SOIL), because, according to them, “there’s no future in the band.” Now that System of a Down has a worldwide recognition, they show their ex-bandmembers how they persevered despite their lack of hope and support.

The music has a mixture of rock, metal and reggae. The song never reached any chart, although it’s one of the band’s most streamed songs.

songs.embed_content: Read “Radio/Video” by System of a Down on Genius

body.plain:
“Radio/Video” is dedicated to the band members that left the band in the early years (when the band was named SOIL), because, according to them, “there’s no future in the band.” Now that System of a Down has a worldwide recognition, they show their ex-bandmembers how they persevered despite their lack of hope and support.

The music has a mixture of rock, metal and reggae. The song never reached any chart, although it’s one of the band’s most streamed songs.

body.plain:
System of a Down, also known by the acronym ‘SOAD’ and often shortened to ‘System,’ are an Armenian four-piece rock band from Southern California, formed in 1994.




The band achieved commercial success with the release of five studio albums, and Toxicity, Mezmerize and Hypnotize have all debuted at number one on the Billboard 200. System of a Down has been nominated for four Grammy Awards, and their song “B.Y.O.B.” won the Best Hard Rock Performance of 2006.



(Toxicity’s album art)

The group briefly disbanded in August 2006 and reunited in November 2010, embarking on a tour for the following three years. They had two subsequent worldwide tours in 2015 and 2017.

System of a Down has sold over 40 million records worldwide, and two of their singles, “Aerials” and “Hypnotize,” reached number one on Billboard’s Alternative Songs chart.




The band currently consists of four Armenian Americans:

Serj Tankian: lead vocals, keyboards, guitar on occasion.
Daron Malakian: vocals, guitar.
Shavo Odadjian: bass, backing vocals.
John Dolmayan: drums.



(SOAD’s actual formation)

annotatable.title: System of a Down
